name: Ise Grand Shrine
shortDescription: Japan's most sacred Shinto shrine complex, dedicated to Amaterasu and housing the sacred mirror
fullDescription: Ise Grand Shrine (‰ºäÂã¢Á•ûÂÆÆ, Ise Jing≈´), formally known as Jing≈´, is the most sacred Shinto shrine in Japan, dedicated to the sun goddess Amaterasu. Located in Ise, Mie Prefecture, the shrine complex consists of two main shrines: the Inner Shrine (Naiku) enshrining Amaterasu and housing the sacred mirror Yata no Kagami, and the Outer Shrine (Geku) dedicated to Toyouke-Omikami, the goddess of agriculture. According to tradition, Princess Yamatohime established the shrine around 2,000 years ago after searching for a permanent home for Amaterasu's sacred mirror. The shrine is rebuilt every 20 years in the Shikinen Sengu ceremony, preserving ancient architectural techniques and ensuring spiritual renewal. Only the Imperial family and head priests may enter the innermost sanctum. The shrine represents the heart of Shinto and the spiritual connection between the Japanese people, the Emperor, and Amaterasu.

events.name: Establishment by Princess Yamatohime
events.description: The princess found the perfect location for Amaterasu's mirror after a long journey

events.name: Shikinen Sengu (20-Year Rebuilding)
events.description: Every 20 years, the shrine is completely rebuilt on adjacent land, then the kami is transferred

inhabitants.name: Toyouke-Omikami
inhabitants.role: Deity of Outer Shrine, provides food to Amaterasu

mythologyContexts.usage: Ise Grand Shrine is the spiritual heart of Shinto and Japan. The Emperor makes pilgrimages to report important events to Amaterasu. Every Japanese aspires to visit Ise at least once in their lifetime. The shrine's 20-year rebuilding cycle (Shikinen Sengu) symbolizes death and rebirth, impermanence and renewal. The Inner Shrine houses the sacred mirror given by Amaterasu to Ninigi, making it the physical manifestation of the sun goddess's presence on earth.
names: Jing≈´ (Á•ûÂÆÆ) - The Shrine (no other qualifier needed)
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Ise represents the center of Shinto spirituality, the connection between heaven and earth, and the continuity of Japanese tradition. The cypress wood architecture symbolizes purity and simplicity. The 20-year rebuilding represents renewal, the passing of tradition to new generations, and the Buddhist concept of impermanence integrated into Shinto. The mirror housed within represents truth, wisdom, and Amaterasu's eternal presence.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Ise receives over 6 million visitors annually. The Shikinen Sengu rebuilding involves years of preparation and preserves ancient carpentry skills. The shrine cannot be photographed beyond certain points, preserving mystery and sanctity. Ise defines the aesthetics of Shinto architecture: unpainted cypress, thatched roofs, and harmonious integration with nature. The shrine validates Imperial authority through its connection to Amaterasu.

images.caption: The most sacred shrine in Japan
